Literature Review: Transcription–replication conflicts (TRCs) represent a significant source of genomic instability, arising from the collision between the transcription and replication machineries on the same DNA template. These conflicts are not only prevalent across both prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms but also pose a substantial threat to genomic integrity by inducing DNA damage and hindering the faithful replication of the genome. Recent studies have shed light on the genomic locations prone to TRCs and the cellular mechanisms that have evolved to prevent, mitigate, or resolve these conflicts, particularly in multicellular eukaryotes where the coordination of replication and transcription is further complicated by cell type–specific gene expression and higher-order chromatin organization. The replication machinery, or replisome, and RNA polymerase (RNAP) are central players in TRCs. The replisome is responsible for the accurate and complete duplication of the genome, while RNAP synthesizes RNA from a DNA template. When these two complexes encounter each other on the same stretch of DNA, the potential for conflict arises, leading to replication stress and genomic instability. The nature of these conflicts can vary, including head-on collisions, where the replisome and RNAP move in opposite directions, and co-directional encounters, where both machineries move in the same direction but at different speeds. Research has identified several genomic regions that are hotspots for TRCs, including highly transcribed genes, regions with complex secondary structures, and areas of the genome that are late-replicating. These regions are particularly susceptible to conflicts due to the increased likelihood of the replisome and RNAP encountering each other. Moreover, the presence of transcription factors and other DNA-binding proteins can exacerbate the situation by further obstructing the path of the replication machinery. To counteract the detrimental effects of TRCs, cells have developed a variety of strategies. One such mechanism is the temporal separation of transcription and replication, ensuring that these processes do not occur simultaneously on the same DNA segment. This can be achieved through the regulation of origin firing, the process by which replication is initiated at specific sites along the DNA. By controlling when and where replication begins, cells can minimize the overlap between replication and transcription activities. Another protective mechanism involves the recruitment of DNA repair proteins to sites of TRCs. These proteins can help to resolve the conflicts by repairing any DNA damage that occurs and by facilitating the restart of stalled replication forks. Additionally, certain proteins have been identified that can directly prevent the collision between the replisome and RNAP, either by altering the speed or direction of the replication machinery or by temporarily halting transcription. The study of TRCs has also revealed the importance of chromatin structure in the prevention and resolution of these conflicts. Higher-order chromatin organization can influence the accessibility of the DNA to both the replication and transcription machineries, thereby affecting the likelihood of conflicts. For example, the compaction of chromatin can serve as a barrier to the progression of the replisome, while the opening of chromatin can facilitate transcription but also increase the risk of TRCs. In multicellular eukaryotes, the complexity of coordinating replication and transcription is further amplified by the need to regulate these processes in a cell type–specific manner. Different cell types express distinct sets of genes, and this differential gene expression must be carefully coordinated with the replication program to avoid conflicts. Moreover, the three-dimensional organization of the genome within the nucleus plays a crucial role in this coordination, as it can influence the spatial distribution of replication and transcription activities. In conclusion, TRCs are a significant source of genomic instability, with the potential to cause DNA damage and compromise genome integrity. The study of these conflicts has provided valuable insights into the mechanisms that cells employ to prevent, mitigate, or resolve TRCs, highlighting the importance of temporal and spatial coordination of replication and transcription activities. As research in this area continues, it will be crucial to further elucidate the complex interplay between the replication and transcription machineries, chromatin structure, and cell type–specific gene expression in the context of TRCs.
